title: Coronation Street's Katie McGlynn reveals Sinead Tinker's death has affected her mental health
text:
Katie McGlynn has revealed Sinead Tinker's death has affected her mental health.

The actress, 26, appeared on Loose Women on Monday to discuss Sinead's battle with cervical cancer, which will culminate in the character passing away on Friday's upcoming episode of Coronation Street.

'I kind of underestimated the affect it’s had on my mental health,' Katie told the panel. 'Part of me is grieving Sinead and it’s bizarre.'

Harrowing: Katie McGlynn has said Sinead Tinker's death has affected her mental health

Katie continued: 'I’ve started doing a fitness thing to safeguard myself. I sound silly saying it but I believe Sinead’s real and I feel like she’s my friend. Watching her die was awful.'

The soap star explained she wanted the cancer storyline to be the character's demise, so as to raise awareness of the importance of smear tests.

She said: 'I’ve been there about six and a half years now. When we first discussed this storyline, I wanted a big storyline but I wasn’t aware they would put this to me.

Time to say goodbye: Corrie fans will say goodbye to Sinead, as she passes away in a scene that is expected to leave viewers in tears

'I said, I love this storyline, I really want to do it. I thought, if I’m doing this, I want to do it properly.

'People do die of cervical cancer, young people die of cancer. I wanted to highlight that people are dying of cancer.'

Katie said the cast were in tears when they watched her final hospital bed scenes during a press night last Monday.

She said: 'I watched the press screening on Monday of her final scenes and I can’t watch it again.

Loss: 'I kind of underestimated the affect it’s had on my mental health,' Katie told the panel. 'Part of me is grieving Sinead and it’s bizarre'

'When we were filming it, you immerse yourself in the part so much. When we went back to Sinead’s room, people were on and off crying. It felt so real. All of it felt real for me.

Katie added: 'We wanted to highlight that you can get cancer in and around pregnancy.

'When we first had the meeting with Mummy’s Star, they were telling me about it and I felt ignorant because I didn’t even know that could happen.

Real life: The soap star explained she wanted the cancer storyline to be the character's demise, so as to raise awareness of the importance of smear tests

She said: 'I said, I love this storyline, I really want to do it. I thought, if I’m doing this, I want to do it properly. People do die of cervical cancer, young people die of cancer'

'I’ve had women messaging me saying they weren’t going for a scan and now they have and they found cancerous cells.

'Me and Rob are always saying it’s imposter syndrome.

People are coming up saying "thank you for this storyline" and I’m just thinking, I’m acting this storyline, I’m not curing cancer.'

Corrie fans will say goodbye to Sinead, as she passes away in a scene that is expected to leave viewers in tears.

But her final days are not without drama, as a devastated Daniel kisses Bethany Platt (Lucy Fallon) in the midst of trying to drink away his pain.

While he does come clean to his wife before her passing, she forgives him before dying peacefully with son Bertie at her side.

The hour long episode airs on Friday at 7.30pm on ITV.
